column1: The COVID-19 pandemic in Indonesia is part of the ongoing worldwide pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). It was confirmed to have spread to Indonesia on 2 March 2020
column2: after a dance instructor and her mother tested positive for the virus. Both were infected from a Japanese national.By 9 April
column3: the pandemic had spread to all 34 provinces in the country. Jakarta
column4: East Java
column5: and West Java are the worst-hit provinces
column6: together accounting almost 50% of the national total cases. The largest increase of new cases in a single day occurred on 8 October
column7: when 4
column9: 810 recoveries and 160 fatalities were ever recorded within a span of 24 hours. On 13 July
column10: the recoveries exceeded active cases for the first time.As of 17 October
column14: ahead of the Philippines. In terms of death numbers
column15: Indonesia ranks third in Asia and 16th in the world. Review of data
column17: indicated that the number of deaths may be much higher than what has been reported as those who died with acute COVID-19 symptoms but had not been confirmed or tested were not counted in the official death figure.Indonesia has tested

column1: people against its 269 million population so far
column2: or around 9
column3: 295 people per million. The World Health Organization has urged the nation to perform more tests
column4: especially on suspected patients.Instead of implementing a nationwide lockdown
column5: the government had approved large-scale social restrictions (Indonesian: Pembatasan Sosial Berskala Besar
column6: abbreviated as PSBB) for some regencies and cities. Starting from late May
column7: they began to apply new normal
column8: along with another green and yellow zone regions. This policy received much criticism and is considered as a 'disaster' due to the still increasing number of cases.

column2: the government only published the numbers of actual people being tested. Since 15 April
column3: the government changed the method of its counting
column4: now also publishing the actual numbers of tested specimens
column5: which is used on this chart. On 11 June
column6: the government published the numbers of actual people being tested the next morning due to delay in reporting from several labs. Tested specimens reported on Mondays and day after public holidays are normally lower as most testing labs are closed on the day before.

column2: the World Health Organization (WHO) confirmed that a novel coronavirus was the cause of a respiratory illness in a cluster of people in Wuhan
column3: Hubei
column4: China
column5: which was reported to the WHO on 31 December 2019.The case fatality ratio for COVID-19 has been much lower than SARS of 2003
column6: but the transmission has been significantly greater
column7: with a significant total death toll.

column2: Indonesia reported zero cases of COVID-19
column3: despite being surrounded by infected countries such as Malaysia
column4: Singapore
column5: the Philippines
column6: and Australia. Flights from countries with high infection rate
column7: including South Korea and Thailand
column8: also continued to operate. Health experts and researchers at Harvard University in the United States expressed their concerns
column9: saying that Indonesia is ill-prepared for an outbreak and there could be undetected COVID-19 cases.On 2 March 2020
column10: Indonesian president Joko Widodo announced the first cases in the country: a dance instructor and her mother in Depok
column11: West Java. Both of them had held a dance class at a restaurant in Kemang
column13: which was attended by more than a dozen people. One of whom was a Japanese
column14: who was later tested positive for the COVID-19 in Malaysia. As Malaysia reported the case
column15: the government of Indonesia began to trace anyone who have had close contact with the Japanese and the infected Indonesians.The cluster was initially identified as the "Jakarta cluster" or the "dance class cluster"
column16: owing to the location of the infection. Since then
column17: confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Indonesia began to increase slowly. By 8 March
column18: a total of 6 people who had attended the dance class were infected by the COVID-19
column19: including one case of repatriated Indonesian from the Diamond Princess. Several COVID-19 cases in West Java and Jakarta were found to have a link with the cluster.The positive cases first confirmed in March are not the first Indonesians to have been infected with the SARS-CoV-2 virus. In January
column20: an Indonesian maid in Singapore contracted the virus from her employer.The first confirmed death of COVID-19 in the country occurred on 11 March when a 53-year-old British citizen in Bali died. However
column21: a Telkom employee who died on 3 March was found positive on 14 March.A newborn baby who died in Manado
column22: North Sulawesi on 19 May was declared as the youngest COVID-19 patient and fatality in Indonesia. On 11 April
column23: an 11-month-old infant died at Bahteramas Regional General Hospital
column24: Kendari while still under Patient Under Supervision (PDP) status. On 30 May
column25: a centenarian from Surabaya had recovered
column26: making her the oldest person to recover from COVID-19 in the country.

column2: the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Indonesia classifies people involved with COVID-19 into four levels:

column1: A suspect is a person showing symptoms of respiratory infections
column2: and has stayed within 14 days in any country or any region in Indonesia with local transmission and/or has established contact within 14 days with a confirmed or probable case and/or requires treatment at the hospital and has no possible diagnosis of other diseases.

column1: A probable case is a person
column2: alive or deceased
column3: who shows or showed obvious signs of COVID-19 symptoms and awaiting results of his or her swab test.

column1: A confirmed case is a person whose sample produced positive results based on swab or molecular rapid test. A confirmed case may be symptomatic or asymptomatic. Due to lower accuracy and higher chance of false positives
column2: a positive rapid or antibody test is not counted into the official number of cases.

column1: A close contact is a person who established contact with a probable or confirmed case between 2 days before and 14 days after symptoms show up
column2: or the date of testing for asymptomatic cases. He or she must be quarantined for 14 days. Reclassification into suspect may be done should he or she show symptoms.Other classifications include:

column1: A recovered case is recorded after a confirmed case is discharged from isolation. For an asymptomatic case
column2: it is 10 days after a sample testing; for a symptomatic case
column3: it is after a swab test or 10 days after onset of symptoms
column4: and at least 3 days after no fever or respiratory difficulties.

column1: Deaths are a combination of both the number of deceased probable and confirmed cases.
According to the Ministry of Domestic Affairs
column2: a regency or municipality may be classified into three levels depending on the severity of COVID-19 cases within the region
column3: according to these parameters:

column1: The number of positive cases within 14 days
The number of suspected cases within 14 days
The number of deaths buried according to COVID-19 protocol within 14 days
Threat of disease contagions to healthcare workersEach has a score of 15 points for increasing trends
column2: 20 for stationary trends
column3: and 25 for decreasing trends.

column1: The three levels will be assigned to a specific region:
Red Zone if the total score reaches below 80 points. Large-scale social restrictions may be enforced.
Yellow Zone if the total score reaches 80 to 95 points.
Green Zone if the total score reaches 100 points (all 4 parameters show a decreasing trend).
Jakarta became the first province that confirmed COVID-19 cases
column2: while Gorontalo was the last to do so. On 6 July
column3: Jambi became the last province to report a death
column4: 53 days after the penultimate province East Nusa Tenggara did. Jakarta set a record for most cases in a single day by a province with 1
column5: 398 cases
column6: beating the previous record held by West Java with 962 cases. Java is currently the epicenter of the pandemic since it has more cases than all other regions combined. Furthermore
column7: four most affected provinces are located on the island.

column1: Indonesia banned all flights from and to mainland China starting from 5 February. The government also stopped giving free visa and visa on arrival for Chinese nationals. Those who live or have stayed in mainland China in the previous 14 days have been barred from entering or transiting through Indonesia. Indonesians are discouraged from travelling to China.Starting on 8 March
column2: travel restrictions expanded to include Daegu and Gyeongsangbuk-do in South Korea
column3: Lombardy
column4: Veneto and Emilia-Romagna regions of Italy
column5: and Tehran and Qom in Iran. Visitors with travel history within these countries but outside the aforementioned regions have to provide a valid health certificate during check in for all transportation into Indonesia. Despite the restriction on travellers from South Korea
column6: Indonesia is still allowing flights from the country.The Ministry of Health ordered the installation of thermal scanners for at least 135 airport gates and port docks
column7: and announced that provisioning over 100 hospitals with isolation rooms (to WHO-recommended standards) would begin. Starting on 4 March
column8: Jakarta MRT also began scanning the temperature of passengers entering the stations and denying access to those with symptoms of high fever. Other public places such as mall and school also began to scan people at all their entrances.After the first victim died
column9: the Indonesian government admitted that they have difficulties in detect incoming imported cases on airports
column10: doing contact tracing and also location history for each case.The Indonesian government plans to turn a site on Galang Island
column11: previously used as a refugee camp for Vietnamese asylum seekers into a 1
column12: 000-bed medical facility specially equipped to handle the coronavirus outbreak and other infectious diseases.On 13 March
column13: the government designated 132 treatment facilities across Indonesia. On 18 March 227 additional hospitals (109 military hospitals
column14: 53 police Hospitals and 65 state-owned enterprises hospitals) are provisioned to cover more patients across the country. The government also established the COVID-19 Response Acceleration Task Force. Doni Monardo has been appointed to lead this team. On the same day
column15: Minister of Home Affairs Tito Karnavian urged all of Indonesian regional leaders to suspend all non-essential travel to foreign country.On 15 March
column16: President Widodo has called on all Indonesians to practice what epidemiologists call social distancing to slow the spread of COVID-19 in the country. Indonesian tax authorities announced that they will move back the tax reporting deadline to 30 April 2020.On 16 March
column17: the Ministry of State-Owned Enterprises instructed its employees age 50 or above to work from home. President Joko Widodo also clarified that the decision to implement lockdown on cities or regencies are only to be made after consultation with the central government.As schools were closing in some regions
column18: Minister of Education Nadiem Makarim announced readiness of the Ministry of Education to assist schools in online learning by providing free teaching platforms. Minister of Finance Sri Mulyani also announced a shifting of infrastructure budget of 1 trillion IDR into healthcare and pandemic prevention.

column1: Specific regions can apply for a request for large-scale social restrictions (PSBB) to the Ministry of Health alongside proof of endemic and mitigation steps. Should it be approved

column1: Health experts are concerned that the country is failing to identify the transmission of the virus. Marc Lipsitch
column2: professor of epidemiology at the Harvard T. H. Chan School of Public Health
column3: "analysed air traffic out of the Chinese city at the centre of the outbreak in China and suggested in a report ... that Indonesia might have missed cases" of coronavirus disease 2019. Western diplomats as well as local and international news outlets postulated that the lack of cases within Indonesia result from inadequate testing and under reporting
column4: as opposed to sheer luck and divine intervention.On 22 March

column1: === Budget for foreign social media influencers ===
The government faced backlash after instead pledging to set aside IDR 72 billion ($5m) to pay for social media influencers to attract tourists to Indonesia.
Indonesian president Joko Widodo is also criticized by Indonesian Chamber of Commerce and Industry
column2: human rights groups
column3: and also by political party such as Golkar and PKS for lack of transparency regarding the information of the COVID-19. Widodo have insisted not to share the travel history details of the patients that tested positive with coronavirus in an attempt to reduce panic and uneasiness in the general public. The public had asked the government to release official national map of COVID-19 confirmed cases' location
column4: as unofficial independent maps may provide incorrect data.

column1: Reports have surfaced about patients in Greater Jakarta having to wait for a long time to get tests or treatment for possible cases of the novel coronavirus disease (COVID-19) as referral hospitals face the increasing strain.
Joko Widodo has come under increased pressure to impose a partial lockdown on virus-plagued areas
column2: with scientists saying the country is racing against time to curb the spread of COVID-19 before Eid al-Fitr and that a community quarantine could be the only solution to do exactly that. On 16 March
column3: Jokowi said lockdown policies are the authority of the central government
column4: and warned the local government to not impose lockdown without the consent of the central authority.On 27 March
column5: dozens of Indonesian medical professors have called for "local lockdowns"
column6: saying that the government's policy of physical distancing is not "effective". The government is drafting a regulation (PP) to stipulate the procedures and requirements for imposing regional quarantines.

column1: Some critics of the government have been arrested for allegedly spreading false information about the coronavirus pandemic.
=== Additional death rates excluded from official counts ===
According to a report from Reuters
column2: as of 28 April 2020
column3: there were around 2
column4: 200 patients who had died with coronavirus symptoms
column5: but not included into the official death toll of 693. This suggests that Indonesia has a higher death rate than the official counts. An analysis by Financial Times showed that there were 1
column6: 400 more deaths in Jakarta compared to the historical average number of deaths in March and April. This excess deaths figure is 15 times the official figure of 90 COVID-19 deaths in this same period.

column1: Ramadan exodus contributed to the spread of the virus in Indonesia

This has caused scientists to raise concern that this evasion will lead to the diseases which can spread easily from Jakarta and nearby satellite cities
column5: where it is the epicenter of the pandemic

column1: === Lack of safety in tobacco industries ===
Despite the temporary closure of HM Sampoerna due to two workers dying from COVID-19
column2: with additional 63 workers tested positive
column3: Pandu Riono
column4: the epidemiologist from University of Indonesia reported that other cigarette factories in East and West Java will continue to operate without practicing social distancing and workers never wearing face masks. This sparks concern that the cigarette factories could create new clusters for the coronavirus outbreak considering that this industry usually has large workforce.

column1: In the first weeks of the pandemic
column2: surgical face masks in Indonesia soared in price by over six times the original retail value from around IDR 30
column3: 000 to IDR 185
column4: 000 (some sources said it exceeds IDR 300
column5: 000) per box in some outlets after the announcement of two citizens tested positive for the coronavirus. Panic buying was reported since mid-February before the first cases were confirmed. President of Indonesia Joko Widodo condemned the hoarding of face masks and hand sanitizers and Indonesian National Police started to crack down on suspected hoarders.

column1: Following the worldwide trend of stock price drops
column2: the IDX Composite weakened even before the first confirmation of the disease in Indonesia. In response to expected economic slowdown in Indonesia due to loss of Chinese economic activity
column3: Bank Indonesia cut its interest rates by 25 basis points to 4.75% on 20 February.On 12 March
column4: as WHO declares pandemic

column6: 937 when Thursday's session was opened

column2: Rupiah weakens to IDR 15
column3: 000 per dollar
column4: touching a level unseen since October 2018.On 19 March
column5: IDX Composite halted because of the sharp downturn of more than 5 percent. This is the fourth trading halt that IDX Composite experienced during the coronavirus crisis. Indonesia Financial Service Authority or OJK have mandated a suspension of trading if IDX Composite fell down more than 15 percent.Numbers of shopping malls started to voluntarily close due to declining foot traffic; only pharmacies
column6: groceries and ATM still operate with limited hours.Indonesian Finance Minister predicted that Indonesian economic growth Q2 can drop to 0.3 percent or even minus 2.6 percent
column7: but in Q3 can recover to 1.5 to 2.8 percent.Indonesia's economic growth in the first quarter of 2020 stood at 2.97 percent
column8: but it is the weakest economic growth recorded since 2001. The second quarter contraction was recorded to be 5.32 percent
column9: exceeding both government and economists' predictions. It was estimated in August that as many as 3.7 million Indonesians may have lost their jobs. The contraction was the steepest economic drop Indonesia has experienced since the Asian financial crisis.

column2: tourism
column3: and leisure ===

column1: Indonesian tourism has been severely affected. In March
column2: overall tourist numbers fell by 64%
column3: and Chinese tourists by 97%. Bali
column4: where tourism accounts for 60% of GRP
column5: had witnessed its foreign tourist arrivals fell by 93.2% in April. Hotels were taking on a meager occupancy rate
column6: with some hotels experiencing 5% and even 0% occupancy rate due to overspecialization on Chinese visitors
column7: increasing travel restrictions from source countries
column8: and an overall fear of the virus. There was
column10: an increase in interest for domestic tourism
column11: and Chinese tourists which had already been on the island generally opted to extend their stay. All beaches in Bali were temporarily closed for the public.The 2020 edition of the National Sports Week (PON) in Papua
column12: which was initially slated for October
column13: has been postponed until next year. Jakarta ePrix race of the 2019–20 Formula E season will also be postponed due to coronavirus concerns. The city's Capital Investment and One-Stop Service (PM-PTSP) announced it plans to postpone any public events with mass-gatherings from March to April following the news of increasing number of COVID-19 cases to 27.Numerous music events such as by Rich Brian
column19: and electronic dance music festival "We Are Connected" has been suspended in the country.
